Award.AwardTitle: Dissection of the ERECTA receptor-like kinase signaling pathway in Arabidopsis
Award.AbstractNarration:
Elena Shpak; proposal IOS-843340; Dissection of the ERECTA receptor-like kinase signaling pathway in Arabidopsis

Plant species vary tremendously in size. While California's coastal redwood tree can grow to a height of 350 feet, aquatic watermeal plants are so small that they resemble specks of cornmeal. When variations due to climate and nutrition are excluded, the mature size of plants is determined by their genes. To understand how genes control plant size, the researchers are studying the ERECTA family of genes which regulates division and differentiation of cells in developing plant organs. How proteins encoded by the ERECTA family genes function at a molecular level is not known. Preliminary research suggests that two novel proteins are involved in a cascade of events called the ERECTA signaling pathway. One of the proteins might control the stability of the ERECTA protein. To examine the role of these proteins in plant growth, the researchers will create and analyze plants where these proteins are dramatically reduced or absent. Another goal of the research is to investigate the function of these proteins and the regulation of ERECTA stability at the molecular level using a biochemical approach.

Understanding how ERECTA functions might permit the design of plants with larger edible organs or fast-growing crops yielding high biomass for alternative fuels. ERECTA belongs to an important family of plant proteins called "receptor kinases", and determination of its signaling mechanism might help us understand many other signaling cascades. This project will provide a training platform for high school, undergraduate and graduate students, as well as career development of the new principal investigator. This project also includes integration of the research with efforts to promote science among middle and high school students, through participation in the Tennessee Junior Science and Humanities Symposium and the Tennessee Science Olympiad, and efforts to update and reorganize the undergraduate Plant physiology course.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Living organisms come in remarkable variety of shapes and sizes. Morphogenesis, the development of a particular form, depends on the ability of cells to form patterns and to organize into three dimensional structures. During morphogenesis cells send signals to each other to coordinate their behavior ensuring that correct decisions on whether and how to grow, divide, and differentiate are made. Plants have multiple signaling pathways regulating their growth and development.

This NSF-funded project was aimed at studying how the ERECTA family (ERf) of proteins mediates one of the core signaling pathways regulating multiple aspects of plant development in the model plant Arabidopsis.  ERfs stimulate elongation of plant organs such as stems, leaves, and seed pods. They also control the number of pores found in the epidermis of leaves. The pores, called stomata, are important for efficient photosynthesis and for a plant’s resistance to drought. During this project we discovered a new gene contributing to the establishment of stomata patterning. KOBITO1 is a glycosyltransferase-like protein that was known to be important for cellulose biosynthesis. Our work determined that KOBITO1 also plays an important role in formation of plasmodesmata, narrow channels between adjacent cells. Changes in the size or number of plasmodesmata affect the movement of factors promoting stomata formation.

Our study also uncovered that ERfs promote leaf formation and regulate phyllotaxy, the pattern of leaf arrangement on the stem. In Arabidopsis, leaves are formed in a spiral with an angle of approximately 137 degrees between successive leaves from the shoot meristems, actively dividing tissues at the tips of the plant stems. Phyllotaxy depends on polar transport of the plant hormone auxin. Our research determined that ERfs regulate auxin transport in the shoot meristem, establishing a model for molecular mechanism of ERf function. Analysis of ERfs’ role in leaf formation in tomatoes is consistent with results obtained in Arabidopsis suggesting that our findings are directly relevant to understanding mechanisms regulating leaf formation in crop species.

This project provided for the training of three postdoctoral fellows, ten graduate students, twenty-six undergraduate students (including six minority students) and thirteen high school students. Some of the funds were used to support research experiences for eleven high school students from the University of Tennessee Summer Math and Science Upward Bound Regional Center Mentoring Program.  This program was created to provide research opportunities for high school students from low income families and families in which neither parent holds a bachelor’s degree. Most students in this program were from underrepresented groups.
